Dell F Barnes.
Chicago Mar 21st 1880

Acrostic
Dearest sister.
Ever kind and thoughtful be,
Live for God who reigns above you,
Love for those, who dearly love you,
And in heart remember me.
Eddie
Oct. 30th - '75

A Prayer
1
Father, to Thee, my heart I bring,
A. burdened, temted, suffering thing,
Yearning for more than earth can give,
For strength to rightly, truly live!
2
For guidance not so much, I pray,
my soul knows well the thorny way,
But at Thy feet, would humbly sit,
And plead for strength to walk wiith!
3
No shorter, easier way I ask,
No lighter burden, sweeter task,
No thorn from my unclear wreath would spare
But only plead for strength to bear!

Love.
What is love worth that is never told?
What dross is compared with glittering gold;
The sweetest music to ears that are deaf;
A tree that bears neither flower nor leaf.
Many a heart has broken to hear
A word of love from like that were dear
Many are sold in the market for gold,
Wrecking their lives for a tale untold,
Love should glow as the moon at night,
Shedding a perfect and radiant light,
Love should be deep, and pure, and strong,
Braving all danger - forgiving wrong -
Fine as heaven and deep as the sea
This is the love that I bear for thee.
Avis Gray

Arnie
So this is the end of it all. A picture or two returned. A harty good-by spoken. A package of letters burned. A tear or tow in secret. A heart-throb

3
So this is the end of it all
The sun will shine just as bright
The wind will coquette with the tree.
And the moon make love to the night
The world will roll round and round,
And the years jog merrily on
But we'll never forget the idyl we read
Or the days that are faded and gone.
A Golden Wish
May God's mercy preserve thee,
His power protect
His goodness uphold thee
His wisdom direct
May thy life be a happy one
May sorrow and care
Never sadden they heart
Nor find a place there.

A Token
1.
I shall bless thee for what thou hast been. More than friend, more than aught else to me. For my spirit to-night, in its sadness. Seems happier mid mem'ries of thee. 
2.
I shall bless thee for what thou wert when friends I trusted, proved but friends in name For the star that beamed soft through the darkness. Was thou, still unchanged still the same.
3.
I shall bless thee, while mem'ry doth linger. Dearer, nearer, than others thou art. Roam where I may, years will never Chill? the gratitude deep in my heart.
4.
I shall bless thee how oft when rememberance. To the days that were dear fondly turns. When the spot that is blest fancy pictures. Where the star of my destiny still burns.

It Might Have Been
1
There flowed two strains of lovely sounds. 
Each of the other's current free: 
They seemed to know but self - nor found.
The common joy of harmony - 
Saving in each two tones so sweet. 
Which did in nicest union meet.
2
And so, me thinks, two hearts have passed,
Adown the journey of this life:
Yet, each its own pursuing fast,
Have never blended in the strife -
Saving for one brief joyous spell,
When each one knew the other well.
3
Ah! like the strains of music, then
They seem-ed one in mutual joy.
But, chancing soon apart again,
And bent on separate employ,
Or discord made or, far removed.
Were neutral when they might have loved.

Flirting
1
They stood on the beach at evening 
Under the starlight fair
A youth in the pride of manhood
A girl of beauty rare
2
His face now pale with passion
Now flushed with the sweet glow
Was bent with an eager listening 
to her voice so sweet and low
3
I never knew that you loved me
Never thought you would actually care
And the graceful head drooped sadly
With its weight of auburn hair
4
I'm to be married this winter
Au Revoir! and she offered her hand
And gathering her robes about her
She left him alone on the sand

She looks from her carriage window
With a beautiful, haughty face
A brand and stately woman
In satin and jewels and lace.
He walks mid the crowd of passere
Cynical, bitter and cold
A man too poor grows weary
Too soon grown worn and old
Ah! yes it was only flirting,, 
It was only acting a part
It was only a head grief-silvered
It was only a broken heart.
The Sabbath
The Sabbath is the golden claefs which binde together the volume of the week.
Long fellow

Longings
1
I long for the green grass and the leaves,
And for violets, to grow.
And the pale arbutus, sweet and fair,
Hidden beneath the snow.
2
I long for the south warm winds to blow
Bringing the breath of spring.
And to hear the twitter of swallows near,
And the brooks low murmuring.
3
I long for the weary laden to act,
With the shadows to depart.
And for sunshine & summer warmth to come
Bringing glad songs to my heart.
4
I long, oh, I long, for a faith so sure,
I can feel my Father's love,
E'en though I wait for the glad time late
Till I sing in my home above.
M.C.E.

The Souls Expression
Oh, when with aspiration strong towards high
and hole things the soul essays to give
Expression to some inward thought that

Margarite.
1
yes, you were dear to me once, Margarite,
Dearer by far then the woman whose life
Is bound to my own - and the thought brings but pain
That my life to another than you whisper Wife.
I saw you last night, 'mid the gay thoughtless throng:
Your laugh, as of old, rang out careless and free.
Your eyes on the marry beamed as brightly as e'er
They beamed their soft love - light, in past days o me.
2
We met - For a moment your eyes flashed on mine
A cold, haughty look - a stranger - like glance
But I caught the swift flush of your cheek, and your hand
Trembled soft to my touch as we passed in the dance,
I watched you, and strove - but the struggle was vain -
To act, as you did, an indifferent part.
You carry it well - aye, nobly indeed - 
The sorrow that still entwines closly your heart

3
There, 'mid the whirl of Fashion's wild life
In a litter and lightÂ ; where Pleasure held sway
I dreamed of the Past, of your Past and mine
It was brighter, God knows, than our
Present, to - day,
I watched you and listened. Every
tone of your voice.
Swift and keen as a knife thrust pierced deep
in my heart.
I hated, yet loved you; I pitied, then cursed.
The fate that has parted + still keeps us apart
4
A hand on my arm - a white womanly hand -
A voice at my side, soft as notes of a dove.
Dispelled the old dream and the face raised
to mine.
Was the face of the woman I had promised to love.
I was dreaming, indeed when I plighted that vow.
For I thought that your power, like the Past was no more.
But last night how the fires of that old passion burned.
And thrilled every pulse with a love I dreamed o'er.

5.
You might have been mine - aye. forever my own
But you'd naught but your beauty and 
I - ah, well!
You can crave not a vengeance more cut
the than this:
Your presence has made of the Present a hell.
Why did I meet you? For contentment was mine
I had learned to hold dear the woman 
whose place,
Is here at my side. But between us to-day
Like a curse creeps the shade of your fair
haunting face.

The Long Ago
or
The River of Time
1
Oh, a wonderful stream is the river Time
As it runs through the realm of tears,
With its faultless rhythm + musical rhyme
and a broader sweep and surge sublime
as it blends with the Ocean of Years.
2
How the winters are drifting like flakes of snow
And the summers like buds between,
and the year in the sheaf- so they come & they go
On the rivers breast, with its ebb and flow
As it glides in the shadow and sheen.
3
There's a magical Isle up the river Time
There the softish of airs are playing,
There's a cloudless sky, and a tropical clime
And a song as sweet as a vesper chime,
And the fumes? with the Roses are staying.

4
And the name of this Isle is the Long Ago.
and we bury our treasures there
There are brows of beauty and bosoms of snow-
They are heaps of dust but we loved them so
There are trinkets and tresses of hair
5
There are fragments of song that nobody sings.
And a part of an infants prayer
There's a lute unswept, a harp without strings.
There are broken vows and pieces of rings
And garments that She used to wear.
6
There are hands that are waved when the farry shore's
By the Mirage is lifted in arr.
And we sometimes hear through the turbulent roar
Sweet voices we heard in the day's gone before
When the wind down the river is fair
Benj. F. Taylor

Ps. 45 - 5
Hope thou in God!
Oe'r troubled hearts no sweeter ray appears
Pure and deep its consolation.
Even in the midst of griefs and tears
This vale of life.
Hast many a shadow dim.
Oh! when it falls around thee.
Upon these words rely and look to Him
In sorrow's night hope on
Nor cease when joy illuminates the morn-
God is a loving Friend
Only Trust in Him while passing
Down the valley to the end
E.A.B.
August 29 - 1880

Hope
1
Hope soothes the sad and anxious heart.
With welcome words of cheer.
It lifts the shadows from the way,
And dries the falling tear.
2
Hope helps us in our daily toil, 
It makes us brave and strong;
It sings within our waiting soul
A sweet and happy song.
3
Hope paints the sky of coming days
With colors rich and rare,
It thickly strews the onward way,
With flowers sweet and fair.
4
Hope comes amid our rising fears
And calms them all to rest,
There is for all a solace sweet
In hoping for the best.
5
Indeed we must be sinking low
While drifting o'er the wave,
When we possess no hope in life,
No hope beyond the grave.
E.A.B.

(26)

Evening 

[1] Upon the hills the wind is sharp and cold. The sweet young grasses wither on the world. And we, O Lord, have wandered from thy fold. But evening brings us home.
[2] Among the mist we stumbled and the rocks where the brown lichen whitens and the fox watches the straggler from the scattered flocks. But evening brings us home.  
[3] The sharp thorn to

The darkness gathers through the gloom no star
Rises to guide us, We have wandered far;
Without thy lamp we know not where we are--
At evening bring us home.
The clouds are round us and the snow drifts thicken
O thou dear Sheperd leave us not to sicken.
In the waste night--our tardy footsteps quicken
At evening bring us home.
Oct 3rd, 1880.

Ad Friend? (To the End)
1
Let us forget all the past that was shadow.
Only remembering the peace that it knew
Let us sometimes think of pleasures that blest it
Hopes that smiled 'bove us, and friends that were true
2
Let us remember the past, but in kindness;
Twas not all sorrow--some gladness it wore.
Why should we cherish resentment? We can be
Friends as we have been--that, if no more.
3
I shall remember thee, for 'twere but folly.
E'en now to think what thou wert I'd forget,
Deep in my heart, and beyond all decaying.
Are buried the dreams that are dear to me yet.
4
Let us remember the past that was gladness
Let us forget all its shadow and care.
Let us sometimes think of bright days long remembered--
Hours that were dear to us, hope crowned and fair.

5
No I've no wish to recall it--the Past. There
Let it rest, undisturbed and alone.
The life may it win from the future, contentment,
And thy heart throb more happy and free than my own. 
Owen M. Wilson Oct 3rd--1880

God cares for me.
1
I sat in the door at eventide.
My heart was full of fears;
And I saw the landscape before me lie
Through mists of burning tears--
I thought to myself, The world is dark,
No light nor joy I see:
Nothing but toil and want is mine,
And no one cares for me.
2
And a sparrow was twittering at my feet;
With its beautiful auburn head,
And looked at me with dark, mild eyes,
As it picked up crumbs of bread.
And said to me in words as plain
As the words of a bird could be:
"I'm only a sparrow, a worthless bird
But the dear Lord cares for me."

3
A lily was growing beside the hedge.
Beautiful, tall and white.
And it shone through the glossy leaves of green
Like an angel clothed in white
And it said to me, as it waved its head,
On the breezes soft and free:
"I'm only a lily, a useless flower.
But the Master cares for me."
4
Then it seemed that the hand of the loving Lord
Over my head was laid.
And he said to me: "O faithless child,
Wherefor are thou dismayed?
I clothe the lilies. I feed the birds.
I see the sparrows fall;
Nothing escapes my watchful eye
My kindness is over all.
Oct 3--1880

coming years with rosy colors. Like flowers at her feet--flowers that are fragrant with the sweet breath of Lome-life. She gathers up in her young heart many a beautiful lesson of love and duty--of faith and patience. They are needed lessons, and perchance she crowns them with a Christian's humble spirit and blessed hope. Time steals on--and the day approaches, when perhaps, to mingle among far different scenes, and to take up new duties in life, she comes forth from the garden of her girlhood a woman, with a woman's love and trust. In a measure, she bid adieu to the pleasant garden, to its scenes, its pleasures, and its associations. But the memory of them will be sweet to her; and like beautiful pictures they will never fade away. Moreover the lessons, that have

been taught her in these early years are the sweet unfading flowers that her heart has gathered up along the way. They will shed a glory around her, and let it be what it may, their purport will sweetly and nobly influence all her after life.
Edward A. Barnes
Oct 17 - 1880

"Wrecks"
Sunset's soft flush has faded
Out of the western sky.
and over the busy city
The twilight shadows lie.
A soft gray mist is spreading,
Oer the lake and the distant land,
And white-capped waves come rolling,
To break on the pebbly strand.
The lamps in the streets are lighted,
And the lamps in the vaulted blue.
While the rose-bud holds up her fragrant lips,
To be kissed by the falling dew.
I stand in the twilight gleaming
In the midst of the waters roar.
And think of my boy-hood's dreaming,
That comes back to me never-more.
There are wrecks on the beach by the head-land
And the sailors sleep under the waves
No bell ever tolled for their funeral rites
No prayers have been said by their graves.

Sad? I know of a thing that is sadder still,
Of a life that is wrecked and lost--
Of a brave, proud heart that is struggling on 
Driven and tempest-tossed.
I know of a heart that strove and broke
Of a conquered and humble pride.
Of a spirit, that, tortured, crushed and wronged
Wrestled, and moaned, and died.
I know--pshaw!what do you care?
Be still! I will tell no more.
But this, There are sadder wrecks by far
Than the wrecks by the blue lake's shore.
April 12, 1881.

Preface, 

            Della gives me this pretty blank book. She also requests me to use it for a continuation of my "Notes by the Way." I comply, notwithstanding certain misgivings about doing so. 

Jan, 12, '82

Notes by the Way
E.A. Barnes.
--1882--
Jan. 14--
I do not think it is too late to say a word, or two, about the Holidays that have faded & gone unclear more. I spent them in the midst of clear unclear, loving faces & kind attentions. Among other pleasant events, I was agreeably surprised?--unclear to recieve a pretty purse?--unclear containing $5 in silver, as a Christmas gift, from a Bible class in our church.
With the new Year, I began to read

& study the 16th chapter of Luke. It begins with the un-just?--unclear stewart  & unclear with a vivid picture of hell--which is hard to believe.
So much for a beginning--the beginning of this book--a sister's gift.
Jan. 16--
Faith's Record, for this month came to-day, containing my words, -- "The Birth of the Saviour." I expect to have my little paper another year, at the old terms -- an occasional  poem for publication.
Della has recieved her long-expected box from Aunt Kittie. It came some weeks ago; & its conents were very acceptable. Aunt Kittie also remembered me, with two handsome books.
The smile is the brightest,
When the heart is the lightest.

Jan. 19--
We expect Lillie & the children tomorrow, Friday, to spend the Sabbath with us--that is, if the weather is favorable. They will recieve a warm welcome.
Miss Tillie, Dell's friend, remembers me with a pretty Calender for the current year. Very acceptable.
I am expecting a new Singing book--"Carols of Joy"--by friend Davis. Some time ago I recieved a postal?--unclear from him, saying, that his book would be unclear about the 1st of Jan; & that he would send me a copy.
Jan. 24--
I am forty years old, to-day. This is not a great age to attain; but I think, for a poor cripple like me, it is quite a long life. How true it is, that, along a pathway of life, many a flower is taken, & a thorn left?--unclear!

Yesterday, I recieved a check for $10 from Marshall Field. This is not the only check, for the same amount, that he has sent me, as gifts, within the past few weeks.
Friend Abbey writes that he has two new books in preparations; & wants me to contribute to both. Of course, I shall respond, from time to time.
Della expects company this evening. I shall probably hear some singing.
Jan. 26--
One of my old patrons--L.G. Emerson, has a new Singing book, just out. It is called the "Male Voice Choir." Mr. Emerson writes that I am represented in it; & of course, my heart is glad
A few evenings ago, a young friend told Della that one of my hymns--"Higher Rock"

was quite a favorite at his boarding place. To me it was a word of cheer--a whisper--"Keep On."
I have had my old chair a number of years; but I don't know as I ever thought more of it than I do, at present. I sit in it a great deal,--indeed, it is my chair for eating, reading & writing.
Jan. 31--
Father & mother had a musical  treat last evening. They unexpectedly attended a concert, given by the "Tennesseeans." I was glad to have them go.
I have sent a little poem to "Faith's Record," on approval.
We have the nicest sitting room stove this season that we have had for many years. Della selected it last fall; & we are paying for it by installments.

Paragraph.
The eye has a language of its own. It speaks when the tongue is silent.
---
Feb. 2--
I have the promise of quite a present, in a few days. Miss Tillie--Dell's old friend--sends me word that she will get me a copy of the new song book--that I want--"Male Voice Choir."
Just now, I have some thrity hymns & songs on hand. They are all duplicated, too. This is something that I never had before.
Della has gone out to spend the evening. When she is away for any length of time, it seems as if the side of the house was gone--the sunny? side, too.
We expect Lula Belle down to-morrow night, to spend the Sabbath with us. I hope

the little girl will come.
Beautiful weather for Winter.
Feb. 3--
A postal from Dr Shipman tells me that the poem I sent to the "Record" last Tuesday, is declined. I have another already to mail.
I am reading one of Jean Insgelow's? works--"Off the unclear." Mr. Wills brought it to me the other Sunday.
Lula Belle did not come.
Feb. 7--
To-day I sent friend Abbey, a hymn. & a printed poem, on approval, for musical purposes. I hope he will like my offerings.
I have also another chance to write--that is

to offer some of my pieces on approval. Mr. Emerson gives me this chance. He is about preparing a S.S. Book, to be unclear by the 1st of next August. I shall send him four Efforts, the last of this month.
Dell has two new songs, in sheet music; one of which is this,--"In the Gloaming." Very pretty, I think.
Paragraph.
If we were always well & strong; always happy & prosperous, the hand of town? sympathy & friendship would withhold its sweetest tokens.
Feb. 9--
Guiteau?, the miserable wretch who murdered President Garfield has been sentenced to be hung next June--the 30th. A righteous verdict, I think.
"Faith in Record" came yesterday--much

earlier than usual.
My supply of writing & copying paper is getting rather low. But the Lord knows it; & I am going to trust Him to replenish it in due time.
Feb. 13--
Since my last notes, William, Lillie--the children have made us another visit--staying two days & three nights.
To-morrow is St Valentine's day. I have sent suitable tokens of remembrance to my two little neices--Lulu & Hattie.
I have recieved a postal friend Davis. He tells me that his singing book--"Carols of Joy," which I have been expecting for a long time, is not out yet; nor will it be unclear six or eight weeks. This is quite a disappointment to me.

Feb. 17--
Last evening, Dell took part in a Literary entertainment. She brought home a singing book--"Gospel Male Choir." In looking over its pages this morning, we found two of my pieces. I need not say, how glad I was to see them. I think it is singular how I come across my pieces, now & then, where I do not in the least expect to find them.
Mrs. Orton called the other day. In talking about my afflictions, she suggested for my use, a bottle of St Jacob's Oil. I have procured me a bottle, & should give it a trial.
Feb. 20--
Yesterday (Sunday) I received a call from Mr Wells. He brought me a good book to read; & gave me a silver dollar. What a good friend I have in him!

This morning, I recieved another check for $10 from Mr. Field. What a noble man he is! And how much good this money does us!
This morning, I sent away six pieces, on approval,--two songs & four hymns. The songs go to Mr. Davis; & the Hymns to Mr. Emerson.
Feb. 21--
Yesterday, I had a glad surprise. I recieved a copy of the new Singing book--"Male Voice Choir." Mr Emerson sent it to me It is a pretty book of its kind. It contains two of my hymns--hymns that I wrote years ago. This is the same book that friend Tillie promised to get for me; but I thank her just as much as if she had done so.
One night last week, Lulu Belle was suddenly taken with the diptheria. But with prompt

& proper attention, the little girl was soon out of danger. Since then, I have thought of her, very often.
Last week, I wrote a new secular piece, which I call, "Boat Song." Yesterday, I sent it to friend Davis, on approval.
Stormy Weather
Feb. 25--
I have a word to say about my old song--"Twilight Comes on Mystic Wings." I have sent it on approval, to a Proffessor of music, on the North Side. He is a German gentleman. If anything results from this venture, I should be indebted to Della's suggestions, & the kindness of our friend Tillie.
I have written a new secular song & chorus. I give it this title--"Lay Me Where My Mother Sleeps." I do not

write from experience, thank God!
The days are getting longer. It is light now at six O'clock, P.M.
The Lord is Good.
Feb. 27--
To-day, I destroyed three of my old hymns. I did not consider them good, & I thought it best to get rid of them.
To-day, I recieved a postal from my friend Davis, relative  to the secular pieces that I sent him, on approval, a week ago. He seems to like them.He makes me a suggestion, from which I suppose I might profitt, if I could borrow a certain kind of a Music book, for a-while.
I have returned a note of thanks to Mr Emerson, for his pritty & very acceptable gift--"Male Voice Choir."

March. 4--
The Winter months are over & gone. When I look back & see how nicely we have got along--how our rent has been paid,--& how many comforts we have enjoyed, I think it is simply wonderful. Surely, He who hears the prayer, rewardeth all who put their trust in Him.
What happened the other morning--the 17th--has been repeated,--the unexpected discovery that I am represented in two large Music books. The songs in question are old; but it makes my heart glad to find that they are thus? republished. Della made this pleasing discovery.
Mild weather for the first of March.
March. 6--
I have revised one of my old pieces--Gospel Lessons.

Dell has promised to borrow the music book, that I spoke about, as wanting, the other day. Please do so, sister.
I have recieved a letter from Goodrich--my prison friend. It is nearly a year since I have heard from him--only because I have not written myself.
This morning, I recieved a postal from my friend Abbey, relative to musical matters.
A Day of Disappointments
March. 8--
Della brings me the promised Music book. I hope it will give me some idea about writing a unclear song.
From now till the 1st of May, I should be at ease about our rent. And to have our home secured is a comfort to us all.

I have something good to read--four late numbers? of my paper--"Christian at Work"
A peddler calls & Father buys me a little supply of note paper. Thanks.
Dell has a pretty music stool to go with her melodeum. She has wanted one for a long time; & I am glad she has got it.
March.14--
Della remembers me with a beautiful Easter card. Thanks.
Since my last note, we have had another visit from Lulu Belle. She seemed to enjoy her visit; & went home, the possessor of a pretty Easter card--the gift of Aunt Della.
I have had another friendly call from Mr. Wells. He brings me two books

to read--religious works.
I have written two new secular pieces. One I call "Sailor Boy," & the other "Spring Glen" And what is more I wrote them quite easily.
I have commenced to read & study the 19th chapt of Luke. This rich man, though little of stature, was determined to see Jesus, who he was. See, how his perseverance was rewarded.
March 15--
Mother's back is troubling her a great deal, just now. She does not look as well as I wish she did.
Old March is giving us more snow than the three Winter months put to-gether.
Prof Cane, one of my old patrons, tells me, by postal, that he is coming to call

on me to-morrow afternoon.
To-day I recieved another letter from my friend Goodrich, a long, long letter. He writes a pretty hand, & uses beautiful language.
March, 20--
Since my last notes, we have had company--Willaim, Lillie & the children. They spent the Sabbath with us, going home to-day. Lillie had quite a treat, going to church, & also to a Lime? Entertainment.
Since my last notes, I have had my promised call from Prof Cane. He sang for me--one of his own pieces, & two of mine. I enjoyed his call more than I can here express. I should like to see him again. It gives me pleasure to think that I can consider such gentleman, as my friend.
The Season of Lent.

March. 24--
I have secured another chance to offer my song-pieces, on approval. The musical party?, in question is Rev E. S. Lorenz. But I should not send him anything till about the 15th of May.
Mr. Emerson writes again. He is still undesided whether to accept either of my four hymns. He sends me a pritty melody in Mss, to which I am to try & adapt suitable words. I should not think of attempting this task, if I did not have Della to help me. She plays the melody, while I write & revise.
By postal, Dr Shipman, of the "Record," declines another of my poems. I must try again.
Last evening, Mother, Lillie & Della, attended a Church socible. Lillie never thinks of going to Church, or to any entertainment, and when she is with us.

It is weeks now since I have tasted a drop of tea. I got an idea that I was better without it, so I discarded it.
Old March has only one more week to whistle, storm, & bluster.
March. 27--
We have taken this house for another year. After the 1st of May, the rent will be $.17 per month. I often ask myself this question--Where is it coming from?
I have sent friend Davis, on approval, my new secular piece, "Spring Glen." I presume he will ask for others, but I don't think I shall respond again.
Since she was here, Lillie has been quite unwell. I wish my dear sisters might enjoy better health than they do.
Mother & I are interested in a continued

story in the Christian at Work. Lillie brings me two numbers, to-day. Thanks
March, 31--
Our little Willie is two years old, to-day. He is a fine little fellow, & the pet of us all.
Last evening, I wrote a new secular song, with this title--"Ere the Roses Bloom Again." Mother thinks that its sentiment is too melencholly. Perhaps she is right.
Since the New Year came in I have recieved 25 letters & postals. This amount of mail matter, is very unusual for me to recieve in three months.
I have applied to friend Wells for a supply of copying paper. Will he respond?
The Last of March.

Aprail, 3-- 
The children, Lulu & Hattie, have had their photographs taken. When she gets them, Lillie has promised me one of each, to send to Aunt Kittie.
This forenoon, while on his way home in a street car, father had a fainting fit. He looked sick & miserable when he reached home. I do not know any of the particulars.
Yesterday (Sunday) I had another call from Mr. Wells. He brought me a package of writing paper--his response to my application. What a good friend I have in him?
Aprail, 7--
Father's sudden illness on a street car last Monday morning, proved quite a serious matter. It was sometime before they could restore him to consciousness; & he has

(pg. 73) 

not got over the effects of it, yet. He says it is a warning to him relative to a certain habit. I hope & pray it may prove so.
One evening last week, I was agreeably surprised when they handed me a large pack-age of N.Y. Weeklies. Having previously recieved like gifts of reading, I know in a moment, who had remembered me again--Mrs. Stanford. This package of "Weeklies" will afford me light reading for a long time. I have returned a note of thanks. 
I have written words to the melody that Mr. Emerson sent me the other day. Words & music seem to blend quite nicely--thanks to the assistance of my good sister, Della. I call the piece "Oh! Sing to the Lord." I shall send it to Mr. Emerson next week, on approval. I wonder if he will accept it. 
This is Good Friday.

April, 8th-- 
Our land-lady,  for some unaccountable reason, has concluded not to increase our rent after all; but to let us have the place at the old price--$.15 per month. This is more than we ought to pay; but as rents are going. I think we are among the favored ones. 
Last Sunday, when Mr. Wells brought me the package of writing paper, he told me he would keep me supplied, as I needed it. What more can I ask of a friend? 
To-morrow is Easter Sunday. 
Apr. 18th-- 
I have sent my new hymn to Mr. Emerson, on approval. If it suits him, I shall feel as if I had done wonders; for he is rather particular what he accepts.
William, as a letter-carrier, has a route of his own now. He took it on the the 1st of the

month, at good wages. I am glad.
I am tired. But this is nothing new; for I am always tired.
